conclusion: Consider power, collision, and deflection effects to determine which blocks A will collide with and where it will stop.
A is positioned on the right side of the image, facing left.
A will likely collide with the blue block directly in its path.
The collision with the blue block will cause A to slow down and possibly change direction slightly.
After colliding with the blue block, A may deflect towards the orange block nearby.
The orange block will absorb some of A's momentum, causing A to slow down further.
Depending on the deflection angle, A might collide with additional blocks in the vicinity, such as the green or red blocks.
Each collision will reduce A's speed and alter its trajectory.
A will eventually come to a stop after colliding with several blocks.
The exact stopping point will depend on the cumulative effects of all collisions and deflections.
A will collide with the blue block first, then likely the orange block, and possibly other nearby blocks. It will eventually stop after multiple collisions.
